definitions.definition: Having the necessary powers or the needed resources to accomplish a task.
examples: She is able to lift the box without assistance.

definitions.definition: Free from constraints preventing completion of task; permitted to; not prevented from.
examples: In a democratic world you'd be able to say what you thought wherever you were.
I'll see you as soon as I'm able .
With that obstacle removed, I am now able to proceed with my plan.

definitions.definition: Gifted with skill , intelligence , knowledge , or competence .
examples: The chairman was also an able sailor.
definitions.dating_raw: First attested in the mid 16 century.

examples: He is able to practice law in six states.
definitions.dating_raw: First attested in the early 18 century.

definitions.definition: Capable of performing all the requisite duties; as an able seaman .
definitions.dating_raw: First attested in the late 18 century.

definitions.definition: Having the physical strength; robust ; healthy .
examples: After the past week of forced marches, only half the men are fully able .

definitions.dating_raw: Attested from around (1350 to 1470) until the mid 18 century.
Attested from around (1350 to 1470) until the late 18 century.

examples: He was born to an able family.
definitions.dating_raw: Attested from the mid 16 century until the late 19 century.

main_definition: Having the necessary powers or the needed resources to accomplish a task. [First attested from around (1350 to 1470).]
secondary_definitions: Free from constraints preventing completion of task; permitted to; not prevented from. [First attested from around (1350 to 1470).]
Gifted with skill , intelligence , knowledge , or competence . [First attested in the mid 16 century.]
( law ) Legally qualified or competent . [First attested in the early 18 century.]
( nautical ) Capable of performing all the requisite duties; as an able seaman . [First attested in the late 18 century.]
( obsolete , dialectal ) Having the physical strength; robust ; healthy . [First attested from around (1350 to 1470).]
( obsolete ) Easy to use. [Attested from around (1350 to 1470) until the mid 18 century.]
( obsolete ) Suitable; competent. [Attested from around (1350 to 1470) until the late 18 century.]
( obsolete , dialectal ) Liable to. [First attested from around (1350 to 1470).]
( obsolete ) Rich ; well-to-do. [Attested from the mid 16 century until the late 19 century.]
